same problem was reported in the newsgroup - Chuck: this *might* be covered by an existing bug; sending your way to get it out of the inbox

I have this issue as well.  Since the original poster has supplied no detail on when this bug occurs I will give details of my situation in the hope that a fix for my issue will also fix theirs.

I have Eclipse 3.3 with WTP 2.0.

Have a Eclipse workspace that has an EAR project and a EJB project that was 
set up by someone prior to me arriving at this company.

I'm getting a frustrating error with the J2EE Module Dependencies prefs 
screen for the EJB project.

When I change to it this page in the properties for that project it throws 
the following dialog

Dialog Title: Could Not Accept Changes
Dialog Message: The currently displayed page contains invalid values

This J2EE Module Dependencies project page for the EAR project however seems to work fine.

The impact of this bug is severe as it means I cannot link my EJB module to any other new project I create.

If I inspect the /.metadata/.log file for this workspace I see the 
stacktrace at the end of this mail (see below)

If I set up a new workspace with a new test EAR and test EJB project from scratch 
this J2EE Module Dependencies screen works fine.  However I don't have the 
luxury of setting things up again from scratch as this system is already in production and I don't want to break all the 
history with source control (subversion).

I have compared every single Eclipse related file I can find in the EJB 
project (.project, .classpath, /.settings/*.*) with the ones in the test EJB 
project and can see only the most minor of differences.

I will post project files shortly when I try and determine the minimum set of settings files necessary to reproduce the bug.

------------------------

I can set up another workspace with a test ejb and test ear project that work the issue so it seems that means I can't have a broken Eclipse install.  

I also don't think its anything specifically wrong with the workspace because if create a new workspace and check the projects out of source control I get the same issue.  

Surely that means the most likely candidate is a project specific file that is causing some unknown bug in eclipse/wtp to show itself?

Will post project files shortly after pruning.

Interesting...  in the process of pruning the files that are business specific to leave the just the barebones files that produce the issue I found a possible culprit.

In my Application EAR project there is the following default directory structure
/EarContent
  /APP-INF
    /lib

In that directory there are a number of open source jar files but there is also an ejb client jar that a vendor gave us to talk to their product which is written using EJBs (which are not deployed in this workspace but rather in a different EAR)

The moment I remove this jar file the "J2EE Project Dependencies" project settings  for my EJB projects no longer throw the error described in this bug.  The moment I put it back the bug comes back.

If I inspect this so called ejb client jar file closely I see it contains an ejb-jar.xml and a weblogic-ejb-client.jar in the META-INF directory.  This is despite the fact that my application.xml does not refer to this as a EJB module. If I open the jar and delete the ejb-jar.xml file out of it the bug with the EJB modules goes away.

Further thoughts as they come to hand.

I think I ran into the same error.

To reproduce: import this EAR file (you will probably need a JBoss 4.2):
http://www.informatik.fh-wiesbaden.de/~knauf/SWTVertiefung2007/kuchenzutatjsf/KuchenZutatJSF.ear

I found that in "\KuchenZutatJSF\EarContent", there reside two files "KuchenZutatJSFEJB.jar" and "KuchenZutatJSFWeb.war". After deleting them, I could access the "J2EE module dependencies".

BUT this breaks my whole project, because the web project does no longer find the EJB classes. And I did not find a way to re-create the deleted JAR/WAR :-(.

I think I found a workaround for the problems I described in comment #5: Seems that WTP 2.0.1 has a regression which breaks the module dependencies for a JavaEE5 EAR project.
I filed this as bug 205004. The workaround is to open the module dependencies for the EAR project and "repair" them (see screenshots in bug 205004). This must be done each time eclipse is restarted.
